Rather than relying on mainstream media to present their own points of view in a credible way, they are coming up with a variety of new strategies—books, exhibitions, postcards, multimedia, facilitating the work of local photographers, etc.—finding that the viewers they reach may respond differently, and sometimes more deeply, to work done outside the warp speed of the 24-hour news cycle. This is not a completely new phenomenon—photographers such as Don McCullin and Philip Jones Griffiths made devastating comments on the Vietnam War, for example, via books that they had published—but in these complex and chaotic times, where good and evil are not always easy to separate, photographers have found it not only useful but necessary to invest in working methods that allow for complexity, emphasize the actuality of their subjects, engage readers more fully, and assert their own responsibility as witnesses and fellow citizens. The work exhibited here from the Tisch School of the Art’s Department of Photography & Imaging’s students, alumni and faculty, reflect a more nuanced view of recent events and ongoing situations. Jessica Ingram ’s A Civil Rights Memorial makes evident how the secular is so easily allowed to override the sacred, restoring our memory of those victimized by racism; Joseph Rodriguez ’s Still Here: Stories After Katrina , contests the mainstream focus on the spectacular with the enduring, emphasizing individual will; Robert Sukrachand ’s 74th and Roosevelt affirms the individuals and their histories lost in the generic label of “homeless”; Peter Lucas ’s work on Viva Favela in Brazil embraces self-identification as a powerful human right; and Alan Chin ’s conflicting readings of Chinese society through his own search for self weave the personal and idiosyncratic into the simplified public in Hollow Wealth: The Chasm Between Money and People in China . The work by professors Erika deVries and Lorie Novak with New York high school students under the umbrella of the Community Collaborations program furthers a sense that what can be taught must be shared, and the lens of looking points in multiple directions, and not only physically. In the histories of photography it is often the subject who is rendered paradoxically invisible, denied agency. Hopefully in this work it is not only the subjects who emerge, but the citizenship of both viewers and photographers who, rather than voyeurs, prefer to be counted among those who exercise their obligations to their fellow human beings.  Fred Ritchin Curator Professor, Photography & Imaging  Visual Citizenship: Belonging through the Lens of Human Rights and Humanitarian Action Fred Ritchin Joseph Rodriguez Lorie Novak Erika deVries Past Constantiner Fellows  Institute for Public Knowledge IPK, 20 Cooper Square, 5th Floor New York, NY 10003 ipk.info {at} nyu.edu           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs? By belonging we mean three interconnected dynamics:       person’s feelings or identification with a collectivity    that collectivity’s recognition of her or his belonging, and    the practices and material conditions which constitute belonging and exclusion or isolation.       Our focus on belonging directs the gaze to several classical problems of social sciences, including solidarity, social bonds, social integration, differentiation, domination, change and distinction. In examining contemporary forms of belonging, the Working Group sees itself as a descendent of this long intellectual lineage but it does so without reproducing the conventional and theoretically fixed ways to understand the question, originally posed as “what holds society together?”    In asking “how do people belong in the contemporary world”, and doing so from a multidisciplinary perspective, we re-address the original framing of the question by: (1) beginning with an understanding that there are multiple and coexistent forms and locations of belonging, as well as of exclusion, from those rooted in economic exchanges to those rooted in national beliefs, and from those located in the “private sphere” of intimacy, household and kinship to those located in the setting of community; (2) seeing belonging as both a political and personal question, a place of ambivalence and conflict, in which the capacity to belong, and the sense of belonging, is connected to an unequal access to both symbolic and material resources; (3) asking how contemporary belongings are formed and transformed in relation to collectivities, but also the life-projects of “individuals”, who sometimes seek forms of belonging, but other times seek to escape or disclaim them.    Understanding contemporary belonging means accounting for changes in intimacy, family structure and gender roles, the growing importance of transnational ties and communities, the decline in long term wage based employment and unionized labor, extensive migration and redefined immigration policies to mention a few.    Four foci of the Working Group include:       Political belonging (membership; inclusion/exclusion)    Economic belonging (work and organizational life)    Localities of belonging (from the local community and neighbourhood to the non-local or transnational)    Personal belonging (personally significant bonds and personal attachments).       These sub-themes are not mutually exclusive, but overlapping, coexistent and mutually informative both empirically and theoretically. Moreover, in each case we seek to examine belonging in multiple ways: as a political question; in terms of the material infrastructures (from passports to policies to technologies) that make belonging possible or restrict it; as something rooted in practices and social categories, but also agency; in terms of how it is organized; in temporal terms (including biographical but also larger historical transformations); and finally, in terms of those who do not belong or whose belonging is restricted (as for example the undocumented immigrant).
